Award.AwardTitle: The Generation of Ultra-Low Emittance Beams by Downramp Injection in a Plasma Wakefield Accelerator
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to explore a new method for generating high quality electron beams. High quality electron beams are needed for many applications such as electron microscopy, free electron lasers and high-energy colliders. One measure of quality of an electron beam is its emittance. This is because a small emittance beam can be focused to a very small spot size, desirable in these applications. This project will explore generation of extremely low emittance electron beams using three-dimensional simulations of a new electron acceleration scheme that takes advantage of the ability to control particle density in a Plasma-Based Accelerator.

It is now well established that Plasma-Based Accelerators (PBAs) are capable of self-generating ultra-relativistic electron bunches that contain a significant amount of charge, have a short duration, and a low normalized emittance. These beam quantities are often combined into a single figure of merit called the normalized beam brightness. Ultra-high brightness beams are needed in accelerator-based X-ray light sources. While PBA experiments have produced useful beams, they have not yet produced beams with the necessary brightness and energy spread needed to drive an X-ray free-electron-laser, nor the charge and emittance needed as an injector for a future linear collider. This project will explore the acceleration of electrons across a sharp density downramp in a plasma through theory and computer simulations, and through an experiment that will be carried out at the FACET II facility at SLAC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Award Number: 1734315

PI: Chan Joshi

Project Title: The Generation of Ultra-Low Emittance Beams by Downramp injection in a Plasma Wakefield Accelerator

 

Scientific progress can only continue if there is parallel progress in the capabilities of complex instruments that are used in the process of discovery. Two of the most successful instruments of scientific discovery are the high-energy particle colliders and x-ray light sources. Both are based on accelerator technology. Therefore, continued progress is only possible if particle accelerators can generate high-energy charged particle beams with ever increasing brightness. The brightness of a beam is given by the beam current divided by the square of the beam (normalized) emittance- the smaller the emittance, the more tightly the beam can be focused. The existing electron source technology based on radio frequency guns is the limiting factor in the smallest emittance beams that can be produced today. Future linear colliders as well as coherent x-ray light sources will need billion volt (gigavolt) electron beams that have one or two orders of magnitude smaller emittance than possible with current technology. The purpose of this NSF project was to develop an entire new paradigm for generating such beams using a new technology based on wakes or disturbance in a plasma (ionized gas).

 

The idea is based on a process called downramp injection in a plasma wakefield accelerator. Here an ultrashort, but ultra-relativistic (going close to the speed of light) electron beam is used to generate a wake as it propagates across a down ramp region where the plasma density is rapidly decreasing. As the plasma density decreases the wavelength of the wake increases even though the front of the wake continues to propagate at the speed of light. This means that the back of the wake is slowing down. If the tail of the wake slows down sufficiently the plasma electrons can enter the wake from its side and be accelerated by the electric field of the wake to high energies in a short distance. If one chooses the drive beam and the plasma parameters correctly the plasma electrons have almost zero energy and consequently extremely low emittance at the time of injection. Supported by this grant we worked out the optimized conditions for this to happen using realistic parameters available to test this idea at the FACET II facility now nearing completion at SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory.

 

Our proposal for a proof-of- concept experiment now has been approved on the FACET II beamline. It will begin in early 2021 and is expected to last 3 years. The current emphasis is on developing new ideas for measuring these extremely low emittance beams. All the proposed goals of the NSF supported projects were successfully completed on time by the P.I. and his group.
